title: Boris Johnson and Leo Varadkar ‘see a pathway’ to Brexit deal
text:
Ireland’s Prime Minister Leo Varadkar and British PM Boris Johnson (Picture: Reuters)

Boris Johnson and Leo Varadkar have said they can ‘see a pathway’ to a possible Brexit deal.

The British prime minister and his Irish counterpart met at a country manor on the Wirral and said after more than two hours of talks that they believed an agreement was ‘in everybody’s interests’.

In a joint statement they said they would now ‘reflect further’ on their discussions while delegates continue to ‘engage intensively’ behind the scenes.

‘Both continue to believe a deal is in everybody’s interest. They agreed that they could see a pathway to a possible deal,’ the statement said.

‘They agreed to reflect further on their discussions and that officials would continue to engage intensively on them.’

The leaders met at the Thornton Manor Hotel near Birkenhead (Picture: AFP)

In a joint statement they said they would now ‘reflect further’ on their discussions (Picture: PA)

Delegates will now ‘continue to engage intensively’ on the matters raised (Picture: AFP)

The meeting at the 19th century Thornton Manor was seen as a last chance for Mr Johnson to save his hopes of getting agreement on a Brexit deal ahead of next week’s crucial EU summit.

In their statement, the two leaders said their discussions had concentrated on the ‘challenges’ of future customs arrangements and ‘consent’ in Mr Johnson’s Brexit blueprint.

The Irish and other EU governments have objected to proposals taking Northern Ireland out of the EU customs union meaning the return of mainland border checks.

They have also voiced strong concern about proposals in the plan for the new arrangements to require the consent of the Stormont Assembly, effectively handing a veto to the DUP.

The statement said Mr Varadkar will now consult with Brussels while Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay will meet the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier on Friday.

The cautiously upbeat statement comes at the end of a week marked by acrimonious exchanges between London, Dublin and Brussels in which negotiations appeared close to collapse.

Briefings by anonymous No 10 sources accused Mr Varadkar of backtracking on previous commitments to try to find a deal and of refusing to negotiate.

And following a heated telephone call between Mr Johnson and German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Tuesday, they claimed the EU was making it ‘essentially impossible’ for Britain to leave with a deal.

If there is no agreement, Mr Johnson will face demands to comply with the so-called Benn Act requiring him to go back to Brussels and request a further Brexit delay.

The PM has said that while he will abide by the law, he is determined to leave on the Halloween deadline come what may.

Government sources have said ministers are preparing to hold an emergency Saturday sitting of Parliament on October 19.

Many MPs believe that if no deal is reached, Mr Johnson will use the occasion to lambast them for thwarting an agreement, laying the ground for a ‘people versus Parliament’ general election.
